title: Trump Sets Fraudster Free From Prison for a Second Time
summary: The president issued a raft of clemency grants this week, including pardoning a woman he had given relief to once before and a man whose daughter had donated millions to a Trump super PAC.

title: Powell, an Unlikely Foil, Takes On Trump
summary: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, this week tapped a groundswell of support that has been years in the making.

title: As Kennedy Center Rebrands It’s Mired in Black Tape
summary: After the institution’s board declared it the Trump Kennedy Center, a lot of signage around the building is in the midst of a makeover.

title: Trump Backs Down on Insurrection Act as Democrats Take the Offensive
summary: Officials denounced the Trump immigration crackdown in Minneapolis at an unofficial congressional hearing, while the president said he no longer saw a need to send in military forces.

title: Video Analysis of ICE Shooting Sheds Light on Contested Moments
summary: Newly available videos and existing footage synchronized and assessed by The Times provide a frame-by-frame look at how an ICE officer ended up shooting and killing a motorist in Minneapolis.

title: Agent Who Shot Renee Good in Minneapolis Was Trained to Track and Apprehend Fugitives
summary: From Iraq to ICE, Jonathan Ross’s career reflects a 20-year government effort to reshape immigration enforcement with a military mind-set.

title: ICE vs. Ice: Protesters in Minneapolis Find an Ally in Winter
summary: Temperatures are expected to plunge to around zero degrees this weekend. Minnesotans say they will be out in the street, using the weather to their advantage.

title: Trump Has Machado’s Nobel Prize, but Neither Got What They Really Wanted
summary: President Trump has María Corina Machado’s medal, but he is not recognized as the prize laureate. Ms. Machado did not win Mr. Trump’s endorsement to become Venezuela’s president.

title: What’s Next for Cuba, Now That Its Main Oil Supplier Is Gone?
summary: The Soviet Union was Cuba’s benefactor for decades. Venezuela took up the slack, and Mexico has supplied “humanitarian aid.” But the world is changing rapidly, our columnist says.

title: U.S. Boardings of Oil Tankers Reflect Hard Lessons Learned at Sea
summary: Videos show U.S. forces descending quickly from helicopters onto the tankers, two years after a tragic boarding attempt.

title: Some U.Va. Board Members Asked to Resign as Gov. Abigail Spanberger Takes Power
summary: After months of upheaval at the state’s flagship university, a new Democratic governor appeared ready to shake up the school’s leadership.

title: Michael Saylor’s Creative Bitcoin Strategy Isn’t Working
summary: Michael Saylor’s financial alchemy thrust an ordinary software company, Strategy, into the center of the crypto frenzy. It all worked spectacularly, until now.

title: U.S. Lawmakers Meet With Danish Prime Minister on Greenland
summary: Seeking to calm tensions, Republicans and Democrats affirmed that they supported Denmark’s control of Greenland as President Trump vowed to buy it or take it over.

title: Syria’s President Affirms Kurds’ Rights, in Overture to the Minority
summary: President Ahmed al-Sharaa’s announcement comes after days of deadly clashes between government and Kurdish forces that have underscored the difficulty he faces in uniting the country.

title: Iran Protests Quelled Since Deadly Crackdown, Residents Say
summary: “There is massive disappointment and disillusionment,” one Tehran resident said. A human rights group acknowledged that demonstrations had been subdued since Sunday, with thousands of people detained.

title: Canada Strikes Tariffs Deal With China, as Carney Looks to Diversify From U.S.
summary: China will in turn cut its own tariffs on Canadian canola products, Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada said in Beijing on Friday.

title: No Link Between Acetaminophen in Pregnancy and Autism, a New Study Finds
summary: The review looked at more than three dozen studies and found no evidence that acetaminophen increased the risk of neurodevelopmental disorders in children.

title: What Is ‘Metabolic Health,’ and Why Does It Matter?
summary: The definition is tricky, but the effects of poor metabolic health are clear — and can wreak havoc on the body.

title: Mamdani’s Push to Halt Sale of 5,000 Apartments to Big Landlord Fails
summary: The sale of the apartments, whose residents had complained of neglect by management, to a troubled firm is an early test of the new mayor’s ability to deliver for tenants.

title: A $12.6 Billion Budget Gap May Complicate Mamdani’s Affordability Plans
summary: The New York City comptroller, Mark Levine, said that poor budgeting practices by the previous mayor, Eric Adams, had left the city with looming deficits.

title: Dramas Keep Showing Us Hapless Men — and Hypercompetent Women
summary: Several of the past year’s films center on confused, bumbling protagonists — surrounded by women who are anything but.

title: A Conservative Critiques Trump’s First Year
summary: The conservative political analyst Yuval Levin gives Ezra Klein his review of Trump’s first year back in office.

title: The Right Is Furious With Liberal White Women
summary: In the MAGA imagination, white women are supposed to be helpmeets, not harpies.

title: Trump Sets Convicted Fraudster Free for a Second Time
summary: Also, the C.I.A. director met Venezuela’s new leader in Caracas. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.

title: Edison Files Claims Against Los Angeles County and Others on Eaton Fire
summary: Southern California Edison said its equipment most likely started the Eaton fire but asserted that government agencies and other businesses shared liability for the devastation.

title: Man Who Attacked ‘Grandpa Vicha’ in San Francisco Is Found Not Guilty of Murder
summary: Instead, the man was convicted of lesser charges, including involuntary manslaughter, in the death of Vicha Ratanapakdee. The killing became a symbol of rising attacks against Asians during the pandemic.

title: WestJet Backpedals on Economy Seats That Don’t Recline
summary: WestJet, Canada’s second-largest carrier, backpedaled on a new seating plan after videos of crammed travelers went viral on social media.

title: Judge Recommends U.S. Issue Visa to Student Who Was Deported in Error
summary: A federal prosecutor apologized this week, saying an ICE officer made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
